messageBody:
On 1/25/07, J. B. Rainsberger <jbrains762@...> wrote:
>
> 5. If enough schools teach it, it becomes part of the standard curriculum.
> 6. If it becomes part of the standard curriculum, generations of
> practitioners treat it as "the way we do things".



Sadly, there is another scenario that I think is just as likely.

Graduates will have an expectation of waterfall-like processes but their
first real job will be in an agile shop.
There will be heaps and heaps of tests. Unit tests. Acceptance tests. Tests
up the wazoo.
They'll be asked to make some trivial change to a sub-system and tests will
fail - as well they should.
They will be shocked and surprised by the test failures and will scramble
around looking for functional specs and detailed designs.
They will blame all of the ills of the industry on the paucity of
documentation.

There will be a great backlash to plan-driven, up-front design intensive
methodologies and the cycle of history will start anew.
